title: 112_s1534
content: The "Identify Theft and Tax Fraud Prevention Act" establishes criminal penalties for using a false identity in connection with tax fraud. The "Identify Theft and Tax Fraud Prevention Act" introduces penalties for misappropriating someone's tax identification number in tax-related documents, with fines up to $25,000 ($200,000 for corporations) and imprisonment for up to 5 years. The amendments made by this section will apply to returns and information submitted after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 3 increases penalties for improper disclosure or use of information by preparers of returns in the Internal Revenue Code. The amendment raises the penalty from $250 to $1,000 and from $10,000 to $50,000. Additionally, the criminal penalty is increased from $1,000 to $100,000. These changes apply to disclosures or uses after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4 introduces a PIN system to prevent identity theft tax fraud. The Secretary of the Treasury must implement an identity theft tax fraud prevention program within a year of the Act's enactment. This program allows individuals to request a unique personal identification number for their tax returns or prevent the processing of electronic returns without this number. Additional identity verification safeguards will be provided for returns without a unique personal identification number. Individuals can request a unique personal identification number for their tax returns to prevent processing of electronic returns without it. SEC. 5 allows the Commissioner of Internal Revenue to transfer up to $10,000,000 to the "Enforcement" account for tax fraud enforcement purposes. SEC. 6 establishes the position of Local Law Enforcement Liaison within the Criminal Investigation Division of the IRS to coordinate tax fraud investigations with state and local agencies, communicate on identity theft cases, and perform other duties as assigned by the Commissioner of Internal Revenue. SEC. 7 requires the Commissioner to submit an annual report on tax fraud to specific committees, detailing reports received and actions taken. SEC. 8 calls for a study on the use of prepaid debit cards and tax preparation software in tax fraud. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on prepaid debit cards and tax software's role in fraudulent tax returns due to identity theft. A report will be submitted to relevant committees within a year. The Secretary of Commerce restricts access to Death Master File information for individuals who died in the current or following year unless certified under a fraud prevention program. The penalty for disclosing or using restricted information from the Death Master File without certification is $1,000 per violation, not to exceed $50,000 in a calendar year. The Social Security Administration is not required to disclose certain records of deceased individuals to uncertified persons. The information in section 9(a) of the program established under section 9(b) is not required to be disclosed to uncertified individuals. This section is considered a statute under section 552 of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 10. EXTENSION OF AUTHORITY TO DISCLOSE CERTAIN RETURN INFORMATION TO PRISON OFFICIALS. The Internal Revenue Code is being amended to address prison tax fraud. The Federal Bureau of Prisons must submit a plan to Congress on how they will use information from the Secretary of Treasury to reduce fraud. State prison authorities are encouraged to develop plans and coordinate with the IRS to combat tax fraud. SEC. 11. Treasury report on information sharing barriers for identity theft. The Secretary of the Treasury will review federal tax laws and regulations regarding the confidentiality of return information to assess their impact on enforcing identity theft statutes. The review will consider enhancing information sharing between the IRS and law enforcement agencies. A report on the findings must be submitted within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary will submit a report with review results and legislative recommendations to the Senate Finance Committee and House Ways and Means Committee.
